texts.shortText: Unmistakable. Bill greatly elongated, black and curved downwards. Head and neck bare, showing black skin. Eyes brown, eye-ring dark red. Body and tail white, trailing edge of wing black and with loose net of blue-black plumes on rump. Legs and feet black.
Total length 65-89 cm, mass 1250 g, sexes alike.

Global: Widespread across sub-Saharan Africa.

Local/Regional: Found inland and along coast in moister habitats across whole region, except arid western parts.

Mainly found along margins of inland wetlands, grasslands and agricultural lands, but also coastal lagoons and the intertidal zone. Has benefited from human developments and now common on farm dams, sewage works, farmyards, etc. Populations in the Western Cape have increased dramatically in recent decades.

Active diurnally, roosting at night in communal roosts in trees, or on the ground if on islands. Usually forage in small groups, sometimes mixed with other species, such as the Hadeda ibis and Little egret, walking slowly and pecking with the long beak, or running forward to snatch mobile prey.

Taking a wide variety of prey. On dry land take insects, crustaceans, worms, offal, seeds, etc. In aquatic habitats feed on crustaceans, insect and their larvae, fish, frogs, etc.  Commonly seen feeding on invertebrates associated with drift kelp on marine beaches in Western Cape.

Monogamous and nest in colonies of closely-packed nests in trees and bushes, or on the ground if on islands. Colonies often mixed with other species, such as storks, herons, or cormorants. Nest a large platform of sticks and stems, lined with softer material. Eggs 2-5, elongate, rough-white, speckled with red-brown. Incubation 28-29 days, shared by both parents. Fed by regurgitation, juvenile thrusting head and neck into adult’s mouth. Fledge at about 40 days and independent after 44-48 days.
Unmistakable. Hadeda ibis has a shorter bill and is brown to bronze.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 356).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robert’s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 611).
